I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support Mongolia’s energy 
policy to (i) mitigate air pollution; and (ii) ensure a reliable, clean, and secure primary energy 
supply in Mongolia by preparing a methane gas supply infrastructure development strategy. The 
strategy will provide a road map to replace coal with cleaner methane gas in selected and 
prioritized uses. 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the country's Implementation Plan for the Government Action Plan, 
2016–2020 (Government Resolution No. 121)1 and is included in the country operations business 
plan, 2020–2021 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for Mongolia.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Air pollution. The Government of Mongolia approved the National Program on Reduction 
of Air and Environmental Pollution in March 2017,  which set the target to reduce air and 
environmental pollution by at least 50% by 2025.3 The program aims to impose a total ban on the 
use of unprocessed coal with few exceptions, such as thermal power plants in Ulaanbaatar. Upon 
the government’s request, ADB is assisting the government to meet the policy target.4 
 
4.  Air pollution—one of the most serious issues in Mongolia—poses serious public health 
risks. According to the World Health Organization, annual mean particulate matter of less than 
2.5 micrometers in diameter (an indicator of air pollution) in Ulaanbaatar, where about half of the 
nation’s population lives, is 6–10 times higher than the recommended safe levels in the World 
Health Organization air quality guidelines. Pollution levels are worse during winter months (from 
December to March). Burning solid fuel, mainly raw coal and waste, in ger (traditional tent) areas 
(about 220,000 households) for heat and cooking contribute 80% of pollution. Vehicle emissions 
and coal-fired combined heat and power plants are also major contributors.5 Ger areas lack 
adequate public services, such as district heating supply, which have not kept up with increasing 
demand from nomadic herders migrating to the capital city. 
 
5.  Cleaner  domestic  primary  energy  resource.  The  Implementation  Plan  for  the 
Government Action Plan, 2016–2020 aims to develop a master plan for the country’s first 
nationwide gas supply system using unconventional primary energy resources, such as domestic 
methane gas from coal reserves, as well as imported gas. To assist such activities, the Midterm 
National Program, 2019–2023 for the Implementation of the State Policy on Energy has set a goal 
of ensuring reliable energy supply and security.6 The government has conducted similar activities 
 
1  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Implementation Plan for the Government Action Plan, 2016–2020 (Government 
Resolution No. 121). Ulaanbaatar. 
2  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2020–2021. Manila. The TA first appeared in the business 
opportunities section of ADB’s website on 20 June 2019. 
3  Government of Mongolia. 2017. National Program on Reduction of Air and Environmental Pollution (Government 
Resolution No. 98). Ulaanbaatar. 
4  ADB. 2018. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Policy-Based Loan 
to Mongolia for the Ulaanbaatar Air Quality Improvement Program. Manila. ADB. 2019. Report and Recommendation 
of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Policy-Based Loan to Mongolia for the Ulaanbaatar Air Quality 
Improvement Program Phase 2. Manila. 
5  World Health Organization. 2018. Air Pollution in Mongolia: Policy Brief. Ulaanbaatar. http://www.wpro.who.int/ 
mongolia/publications/20180228_policy_brief_on_air_pollution.pdf. 
6  Government of Mongolia. 2019. Midterm National Program, 2019–2023 for the Implementation of the State Policy 
on Energy. Ulaanbaatar.

2 
to this TA by increasing the use of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) under Liquefied Petroleum Gas 
Program (2006). LPG use for transport is now nearly 10 times higher than the usage rate before 
the program, improving the air quality. Although having made success in the transport sector, the 
program has not met the residential heat demand because its supply cost is higher than those of 
incumbent fuels. The government has also studied exploring and/or producing methane gas from 
domestic coal reserves with support from the United States Environmental Protection Agency, but 
the scope did not cover gas transmission and distribution.7 
 
6.  To address these issues, the government requested ADB to support the study to prepare 
the country’s first nationwide methane gas supply infrastructure development strategy. This will 
contribute toward lowering greenhouse gas emissions and improving air quality by switching fuel 
from coal to methane gas. This is in line with ADB's Strategy 2030 operational priorities on (i) 
tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental 
sustainability; and (ii) making cities more livable. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) air quality improved and (ii) reliable and 
cleaner energy supply secured (footnotes 1 and 3). The TA will have the following outcome: 
readiness for investments in methane gas supply infrastructure increased.8 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  The TA team will recruit consultants to provide solutions for the identified problems and 
for the strategy to develop a methane gas supply chain for Mongolia’s heating and power demand. 
The study will cover the gas supply chain as detailed in paras. 9–12. 
 
9.  Output 1: Methane gas supply chain development strategy paper prepared. The 
strategy will cover the entire country and focus on demand mainly from households for heating 
and cooking and partly from small heat-only boilers and selected combined heat and power plants. 
Under this output, the TA team will 
(i)  conduct gas demand and supply forecasting; 
(ii)  assess domestic coal mine methane and coal bed methane resources; 
(iii)  develop basic technical design, such as gas transportation technology; 
(iv)  conduct market assessments, including tariff and institutional design; 
(v)  assess  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  specifically  the  responsibility  of 
relevant ministries; 
(vi)  evaluate the methane gas supply business scheme; 
(vii)  prepare  a  roadmap,  including  a  10-year  infrastructure  development  plan,  a 
preliminary safeguard impact assessment, and an investment plan; and 
(viii)  summarize the above findings into a development strategy. 
 
 
7  B. Mendbayar. 2016. CBM and CMM Development in Mongolia—New Policies to Stimulate Clean Energy Projects. 
Document presented at the Global Methane Forum. Washington, DC. 29–30 March. (CBM refers to coal bed 
methane and CMM refers to coal mine methane.) 
8  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
10.  Output  2:  Prefeasibility  study  report  on  prioritized  methane  gas infrastructure 
projects prepared. Under this output the TA team will (i) identify future investment projects on 
gas supply infrastructure and (ii) prepare a prefeasibility study report on the identified projects. 
 
11.  Output 3: Capacity in methane gas supply infrastructure enhanced. Under this output 
the TA team will 
(i)  enhance the capacity of the Ministry of Energy on the methane gas supply system, 
and organize an international study tour to build the capacity of executing agency 
staff; 
(ii)  organize domestic workshops to disseminate findings, inviting resource persons 
for knowledge transfer of international best practice; and 
(iii)  prepare  a  capacity  building  program  for  the  executing  agency  and  relevant 
stakeholders on methane gas infrastructure and business practice, which will (a) 
deliver a report that summarizes international best practice on methane gas 
infrastructure development and business operation practice and (ii) prepare a 
public awareness program on the use of methane gas. 
 
12.  Knowledge dissemination. Publications will primarily be digital but will also be printed to 
maximize readership. The number of hard copies will be agreed with the executing agency during 
TA implementation. The major target audience will include relevant government entities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.2 million equivalent, of which (i) $0.5 million will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund (EAKPF), and 
(ii) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty 
Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund (PRC Fund),9 both to be administered by ADB; and 
(iii) $0.2 million will be the estimated monetary value of the counterpart contribution from the 
government. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
14.  The EAKPF will finance operational expenses related to eligible activities indicated in the 
fund’s implementation guidelines.10 The fund will not be used for civil works, procurement of large-
scale equipment, permanent staffing costs, or recruitment of staff consultants, unless otherwise 
agreed between the Government of the Republic of Korea and ADB. 
 
15.  The PRC Fund will finance operational expenses related to TA, grant, and other eligible 
initiatives agreed by the Ministry of Finance of the People’s Republic of China and ADB, including 
consulting  services,  training,  conferences,  workshops,  small-scale  civil  works  and/or  other 
associated demonstration-level equipment and materials.11 
 
16.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office accommodation, 
office  supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic  transportation,  information  and  documents 
relevant for the preparation of the TA, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
 
9 The fund was originally named the “People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund” 
in the 2005 Board paper. 
10 ADB. 2018. Annual Report of the e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 2017. Appendix 6: Implementation 
Guidelines for the Republic of Korea E-Asia and Knowledge Partnership fund. Manila. 
11 ADB. 2018. Implementation Guidelines People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation 
Fund (PRC Fund). Manila.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. The Sustainable Infrastructure Division of ADB’s East Asia 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The executing agency will set up a 
working committee comprising the Ministry of Energy, the Ministry of Mining and Heavy Industry, 
and the Mineral Resources and Petroleum Authority to coordinate TA implementation. The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  January 2020–January 2022 
Executing agency  Ministry of Energy 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB  
International consulting  Feasibility study (43.5  $988,500 
firm: QCBS (90:10)  person-months) 
Individual selection  International expertise  $11,500 
(resource persons) (0.5 
person-months) 
Disbursement  The  TA  resources  will  be  disbursed  following  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). Disbursement arrangements for all funding sources will be 
on a pro rata basis. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: ADB estimates. 
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.12 ADB will recruit an international consulting firm to deliver the outputs using 
quality and cost-based selection (QCBS) with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio and a simplified technical 
proposal.13 The  estimated  input  will  be  43.5  person-months  of  international  and  national 
consultants over 18 months. The international consulting firm will undertake the main tasks but 
resource persons may also be recruited as expert presenters at workshops. Lump sum and/or 
output-based contracts will be considered for the engagement of resource persons. 
 
19.  Cofinancier requirements. TA implementation will follow the additional monitoring and 
reporting requirements specific to the EAKPF (footnote 10) and the PRC Fund (footnote 11). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance (TA) not exceeding the 
equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund, and (ii) ADB administering TA not exceeding the equivalent of 
$500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction 
and Regional Cooperation Fund to Mongolia for the Methane Gas Supply Chain Development 
Master Plan, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
13 The 90:10 quality–cost ratio is adopted because the work requires greater priority for the consultant’s quality.
